bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, February 26, 1941

div1.p: Hench comments on Truby's suggestions regarding the Cornwell yellow fever painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George A. Kellogg, February 26, 1941
div1.opener:
February 26, 1941
Mr. George Kellogg
257 Cornelison Avenue
Jersey City, N. J.
My dear Mr. Kellogg:
div1.p:
I was very glad to receive the photographs of the people you met in
Cuba and they are interesting to have. While I am not in a hurry for some of the
material that I loaned you, I am most anxious to have you return at your very
earliest convenience the Agramonte article in the Scientific Monthly for December,
1915. I must have parts of this photostated right away to send in my report to Dr.
Ramos, which must go out if possible in the next week. Unfortunately, the other copy
of this article which I have is so marked up that I do not wish to photostat it.

I have just received a carbon copy of General Truby's letter to you. I
am sure you will find it most interesting and helpful. I am a little disturbed
about his suggestion to make such a large, formal grouping, and I think his painting
would have little action in it. Furthermore, I think it would emphasize General
Wood too much. If you wish, by all means put General Wood into your scene but I
still think that a painting portraying the actual inoculation of Carroll by Lazear
would be the best. It seems to me that General Truby contradicts himself a bit.
In the first part of his letter he says he hates to see a painting depict the scene
with persons therein (meaning Reed) who were actually not there. But then he goes
on to describe a scene which never took place, with General Wood and various enlisted
volunteers also present. However, he undoubtedly wrote you a hasty reply before
having a chance to think over the subject completely. At the moment I still think
my suggestion is a little better because it permits more action in the picture, but
I am a little concerned about the idea of having the scene laid out on the lawn in
front of the officer's quarters. I can well imagine Lazear walking over from Reed's
laboratory across the grass to Carroll, who might have been on the porch, and there
inoculating Carroll (although we know this was undoubtedly done in the laboratory)
but I can't imagine them stepping down from the veranda of the officers' porch to do
this experiment out on the lawn.

General Truby's letter, however, shows such keen interest in your venture
and such a willingness to go along and accept certain artistic license that I believe
in the long run he will be satisfied with whatever the group of us think best. I
shall await with great interest your comments telling me of Mr. Cornwell's reactions.
I shall also be interested to hear of General Kean's reaction to the project. I have
not yet heard from him.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
P.S. Please return the Agramonte article as soon as possible.
P.S.H.
